newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Rainbow flies on hopes for local chickens.
newsitem.headline: Rainbow flies on hopes for local chickens.

text.p: Shares in Rainbow Chicken flew higher on Monday, stirred by talk there could be a turnaround in the local chicken industry, dealers said.
They added that Rainbow had been hit hard recently and that hopes for the industry could have triggered some speculation with a number of players taking up positions.
By 1027 GMT on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange the share had added 16 cents to 124 cents after earlier touching a day's high of 130 cents a share. About 355,000 shares had changed hands.
"There is talk of a turnaround in the (local) chicken industry. Rainbow was hard hit previously by cheaper imports and chicken disease here," one dealer said.
But she added that it was unlikely the South African chicken industry could compete with the lower cost of imported chickens and therefore Rainbow's recovery would be shortlived.
"It could soon start to look a tad overdone. It could steady a bit and then head lower. This is more than likely as the hopes for the industry are likely to be shortlived," a dealer said.
Rainbow, hit by rising feed costs and fierce competition, recorded an attributable loss of 159.8 million rand in the year to end-March on sales of 1.88 billion rand.
Last August 16 it hit a record low of 63 cents.

Dealers said that a recovery in the stock had been expected for some time now and, in addition to hopes for the industry, the appointment of a new managing director may have started to impact positively on the share.

"It's been expected for a while now. Rainbow had a very tough time. The new managing director might be having an effect. Shareholders might have high hopes for him to turn it around," one dealer said.
"It seems like it's mostly speculators taking positions."
